label: Letter to Thomas J. Grimke from Thomas Pinckney, September 25, 1819
description: A six-page letter from Thomas Pinckney to Thomas Grimke describing his acquaintance with Grimke's father. Pinckney attended Westminster School with the elder Grimke and also studied law at "the Temple" together. Pinckney describes his time Charleston during the Revolutionary War with Thomas Grimke's father.

metadata.label: Description
metadata.value: A six-page letter from Thomas Pinckney to Thomas Grimke describing his acquaintance with Grimke's father. Pinckney attended Westminster School with the elder Grimke and also studied law at "the Temple" together. Pinckney describes his time Charleston during the Revolutionary War with Thomas Grimke's father.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Montruville[?] 25th Septm. 1819

Dear Sir,

I first became acquainted with
your father at Westminster School about the year
1767—He was I believe two or three years younger
than me, and within about a proportional distance
between our situation in the School, and we boarded at different
houses, all that I can recollect of him in this situation
is that he was respected by his schoolfellows and personally
stood high in his class. On leaving school I was re-
moved to the University of Oxford and he Afterwards
went to Cambridge: I of course saw little of him but
during the vacation in one of which I entered Cam-
bridge and [illegible] several pleasant days with time [at?]
Trinity College, of which he was a Fellow Commoner.
I found that at College, as at School, he had by his
enviable disposition, initiated the regard by his
[illegible] and gentlemen who conduct, commanded the respect
of his associates. From Cambridge we made together an
[examining?] through [illegible], Cheshire and during
which he paid particular attention to the great Land which
the Duke of Bridgewater was from. completely [illegible]

[End page 1]

appearing to have a predilection for work of such extre-
mely beneficial tendency. I saw little of him after this 
tour until we again met while studying the Law at the
Temple, where I’ve collect nothing more than the [illegible]
occurrences, except that he was one of those who attended the
Meetings of the Americans resident in Land on convened on the
suggestion of Dr. Franklin, Mr. [Curtis?] Lee, Col. Laurius and the mad   
[cancer?] of the British Government, then full driving America
to opposition in arms; on at least to action our [potency?]:
the [illegible] measures they were [illegible]: I recollect
that we had several meetings and I think we [pushed?] the
Boston Port Bill through both Houses of Parliament and finally
presented the petition to the King, a copy of which you
may have lately seen prohibited here from a Boston
newspaper; and his honorable to South Carolina that out of
thirty, the whole number of Americans then in London who
had sufficient [patrician?] to sign there remonstrances,
sixteen of them were her nature sons: for were this op-
position however moderate  [illegible] kept tired for
several who attended in meetings. Your father
cordially cooperated in these circumstances are
also about this time united with several of his young
Countrymen, who foreseeing the consequences of the in-
judicious and [illegible] conduct of the Mother Country to her
Colonies, engaged and [servant?] of the Guards to drill us

[End page 2]

our private lodgings, and endeavoured to obtain
what insight we could into the practice of [illegible]
[illegible].—I arrived in Charleston in December
1774 and received the Commission of Capt. of Infantry in the
first Rag. of S.G. in June 1775, soon after that period your
Father arrived and joined me as a Cadet in my company
but we were soon again separated, as about October
1775 the Regiment of Artillery was raised, in which he
recurred the Commission of 7th Lieutenant.—Except
in the attack on this that by the Sen. Peter Parker and [Ln?] Horry
Charter in 1776; we had little active service in the South
until 1778 when your Father attended Genl. Howe as an
his to Camp on the badly planned and miserably executed
expedition to St. Mary’s River and Florida; where our
Continental Regiment were [illegible] by sickness owing to the
intemperance of the [illegible] and privation of necessary supplies
at the close of that company your father was with first.
Have in Savannah when the British attacks it with a
superior force; and the General having in caution by left unguarded
some [illegible] in the rear of his right flank, his whole detachment
was surrounded, and I [divertedly?] wrote was the consequence: your
farther he heard with great intrepidity and himself, but [irregular]
to maintain order among troops so completely broken in presence
of more [illegible] enemy. I do not recollect in what [guards?]

[End page 3]

he served during the [illegible] of Gen R. [Provert?] in 1779 but I
think he must have been with General Moultrie [of?] Black Swamp
and after [illegible] in Charleston when Prevort appeared before and
surrounded that City.—Col. Roberts commanding the Artillery having
been killed by a cannon shot when we attacked the British lives[?]
at Stono your father was promoted to the Liut. Col. of that Regiment.
Het did not accompany us to the directions siege of
Savannah in 1779, Within the proceeding year he had full
opportunity of giving experience in the attack and defense
of fortified places, [or rather of entrenched Ports, for
Charleston was no more] when [illegible] Horry Clinton broke
ground before it on the 1st of April, and the town was
defended until the 12th of May. I was at Fort Moultrie
until after the British fleet [illegible] it and our Regiment was
soon after removed to Charleston but in a few days I was sent
out by Genl. Lincoln on a special mission, so that I had not one
opportunity to see much of your fathers conduct there, but in the
short time I was in the town, I had a sufficient sample
of the service to know that his exertions as an Officer
of Artillery where that Arm was so eminently useful
and exhorted to such incessant peril must have
been highly meritorious.—In Gen Moultries memoir
you will find an incident in your fathers conduct as a prisoner

[End page 4]

of [who?] which terminated in his being restored to the
service of his Country: but as I was made a private at
the battle of Camden, I can give Gen no farther account
of his military service. After the War he [illegible]
a member of the Legislature and was for some time
Speaker of the House of Representative the duties of
which office he so conducted as to maintain with himself
the dignity and decorum of the body in which he provided, and
[preserved?] under in the debates with impartiality.
He practiced Law but a short time at the [Bar?], having
been soon elevated to the Bench of the Court of Common
Pleas: of his [illegible] there and of the useful [illegible] he compiled
and is unnecessary for me to unite; as Gen might be fully
acquainted with them.

The above, my dear Sir, is a doctor of what I can
recollection concerning you father, it is the result of a
memory never strong and now rendered weaker by old age.
The sincere regard I bore to your father prevent me
from answering your application by stating of how little importance

[End page 5]

my information could be for the purpose for which
you desired it: I thought it here to set down what I recol-
lect as a testimonial of my wishes at least to do [illegible]
might be gratifying to his family.
I beg you to present the appearance of my sincere
condolence and high respect to your Mother, and remain
with much esteem,
Your obed. Servant,
Thomas Pinckney

[End page 6]

[To:] Thomas Grimke Esq
Charleston

[End page 7]
